Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative RUI: Quadrilateral Surface Meshes with Provable Quality Guarantees

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The representation and reconstruction of complex three-dimensional objects is critical in a wide range of applications in computing today. Polygonal meshes have become the industry standard for the representation of surfaces with highly complex geometry and arbitrary genus in computer graphics and geometry processing applications. While triangle meshes are the most popular type of mesh representation for surfaces, quadrilateral meshes are better suited than triangle meshes in several applications such as character animation, texture mapping, spline-based surface modeling, mesh compression, and some specific finite element analysis applications. Provably good algorithms for generating triangle meshes from surfaces given by parametric or implicit functions or as point point clouds are widely available. However, algorithms to generate quadrilateral meshes with provable quality guarantees for such surfaces are not as prevalent, in part because the problem of generating a quadrilateral mesh from a given surface is intrinsically harder than its triangular counterpart. The goal of this project is to develop algorithms for quadrilateral meshes for various surface representations with provable guarantees on element quality as measured by commonly used metrics such as angle bounds or aspect ratio, and mesh quality as measured by mesh size or anisotropy. Direct and indirect methods (which generate a quad mesh from a triangle mesh), as well as parameterization guided methods will be utilized. Techniques from computational geometry and graph theory will play a central role in the design and development of algorithms.

The automated generation of provably good quadrilateral meshes for surfaces is a fundamental problem that is of interest both in theory, as it raises several geometric, combinatorial, and graph-theoretic questions, as well as practice, where the computational pipeline from designing a model for the surface to the end stage of simulation or animation is frequently dominated by the meshing process. A formal understanding of these questions is critical not only for the theoretical underpinnings of automated mesh generation, but also for the sound practice of utilizing the meshes in a wide range of applications.

As a collaborative effort between PIs at three undergraduate institutions, involvement of undergraduate students in research projects is an integral part of this project. An important and particular goal for this project is the creation of a larger peer group for female and minority undergraduate Computer Science majors by providing opportunities for collaboration and joint research projects between students across all three institutions. Through early and active involvement of undergraduates in the project, the PIs also seek to create a pipeline of female and minority students bound for graduate school in Computer Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project is to develop algorithms for quadrilateral meshes for various surface representations with provable guarantees on element quality as measured by commonly used metrics such as angle bounds and aspect ratio. The first main research outcome of this project was the design of an algorithm that utilizes quadtree decompositions to quadrangulate a polygonal region with holes into quadrilateral elements that have bounded aspect ratio and angles between 45 and 135 degrees. The second research outcome is a new algorithm for converting a given triangulation T of an orientable, connected, boundaryless, and compact surface S into a quadrangulation Q by using edge contractions and vertex splittings. The algorithm computes a quadrangulation of the surface in two steps by combining triangle pairings with edge flips. If T has positive genus g, the new algorithm takes O(gn + g^2) amortized time to compute a quadrangulation with the same vertex set, where n is the number of triangles of the triangulation; otherwise (i.e., if the genus is zero), it takes O(n) amortized time. Experimental results establish that if n is large and g << n (which is the case in typical applications), then the new algorithm performs better than other triangle-matching algorithms. However, if n is not large enough or g is large (relative to n), then a fast and simple greedy algorithm, when combined with an effective heuristic to pair up edge-adjacent triangles, is the best option. This work was presented at the International Meshing Roundtable'15. 

As a collaborative RUI award, an important outcome of this project is the research training and professional development of several undergraduate students (and, in particular, women) across multiple undergraduate institutions. This was achieved through the creation of a large peer group of students working in computational geometry, participation in research projects, and various collaborative activities between the participating institutions, including a joint workshop with presentations by external invited speakers and undergraduate students from five local institutions: Bryn Mawr College, Rutgers-Camden, St. Joseph's University, Villanova University, and Haverford College. A significant outcome from this peer group is that five female students have joined top-tier PhD programs in Computer Science, with theory/computational geometry/graphics as their research directions.

At Bryn Mawr College, fourteen students (ten female, four male) participated in this grant. Out of the twelve students who graduated, six went on to graduate programs in Computer Science, resulting in five female PhD candidates (three at the University Maryland, one at the University of Utah and one at the University of Virginia) and one male Masters candidate at the University of Pennsylvania. The other six went to a variety of industry positions (two at Google, one at the Bank of America, one at the University of Pennsylvania, one at ApNexus and one at Nordstrom).

In addition, the following student papers/products were generated:

  • Aspect-Ratio Based Triangular Mesh Smoothing - presented as a poster at the ACM Student Research Competition held at SIGGRAPH 2017. It was selected as a semi-finalist and after an additional oral presentation during the ACM SRC Final Presentation, it was awarded third place in the Undergraduate category. 
  • Quadrilateral Mesh Boundary Classification and Editing - presented as a poster at the ACM Undergraduate Student Research Competition held at SIGCSE 2017. 
  • A total of eleven senior theses were supervised in connection to this grant, out of which six won departmental honors.  

At Rutgers University-Camden, 10 students participated in the project over the duration of the award. Of these seven have graduated and are working in various companies in the software industry (two atVanguard, two at ASRC Federal, one at Subaru of America, one atLeidos, and one at Quintiq-Dassault Systemes). 

In addition, the following student papers/products were generated from student participation in the project:

  • All students presented their work publicly at CURCA (Celebrationof Undergraduate Research and Creative Activity), an annual event at Rutgers-Camden to highlight undergraduate research. This resulted infive research posters, including one that will be presented in this academic year.
  • Poster presentation at the ACM Undergraduate Student Research Competition held at SIGCSE 2017: An empirical study of Robinson's aspect ratio measurement of quad meshes generated by converting a triangle mesh to a quad mesh.
